description.narrative: By the end of 2016, national and sub-national capacity strengthened to plan and budget interventions that promote adolescent health, development and their engagement in decision making processes.,which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Cross-Sectoral Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Health â€“ General, Hiv Prevention, Hiv â€“ General, Human Rights Institutions, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Technical Excellence In Policy And Programmes. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Equitable access to Child-Friendly Schools that are inclusive, academically effective, gender-sensitive, healthy, safe protective, and involve families and communities

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By the end of 2016, national and sub-national capacity strengthened to plan and budget interventions that promote adolescent health, development and their engagement in decision making processes.

description.narrative: UNICEF Mongolia strengthened the policy environment for the promotion of adolescent development with the government's approval of the first policy document on organization of students' extracurricular activities in schools including implementation guidelines, a draft national programme on child development and protection, and an action plan on adolescent mental health. | Status:Met | As-of Date:12/01/2017

title.narrative: Percentage of schools with fully functioning Child Development Centers (allocated space, trained teachers, supportive attitude of school administration and active child-led organizations)

Comprehensive knowledge about HIV transmission of young people age 15-24 years
